comments:
CVS connection don't work when password is required to access remote host, ie.
without storing local ~/.ssh/id_dsa.pub on server's ~/.ssh/authorized_keys.
Eclipse displays 'Unknown response received from cvs server' but the CVS console
is empty. No password dialog window is displayed.

3.1M3 Linux/GTK

Strange. I use password authentication with extssh every day and have not had 
a problem. Could you follow the steps at this URL to see what is being 
exchanged between the client and server. Also, what CVS server version are you 
using?

http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/platform-vcm-
home/docs/online/cvs_features2.0/cvs-faq.html#misc_0

Marking as REMIND and will reopen when requested information is provided.

When run with configuration described on the page you mentioned Eclipse asks for
a password but *on the terminal it was run from*. Actually, it also asks for
password on terminal when run without these options as well.

What connection method are you using?
ext, using ssh as a rsh replacement (CVS_RSH=ssh)

Have you tried extssh? This connection method supports SSH 2. You can also 
configure the EXT connection method to use SSH2 when inside Eclipse in order 
to keep your sandbox compatible with command line tools (Team>CVS>Ext 
Connection Method preference page). If you want to keep using ext, you will 
need to configure the invokation parameters (on the same preference page as 
mentioned above) in order to provide the password. There is no way in java to 
support command line prompts.
Marking as worksforme since this appears to be a configuration issue.

Well, telling Eclipse to use extssh when connecting using ext method did the
trick, thanks for explanation! But then what ext is good for (except for
puzzling users and generating invalid bug reports ;-) )? Shouldn't it be removed
if using extssh instead does all ext does, and works always?

One important thing I think is that, as a minimum, user should be explicitly
told to try to configure Eclipse to use extssh instead of ssh if problem I
experienced is detected. Frankly, by myself, I'd never guessed that I should do
what needed to be done -- if Michael didn't tell me what to do I would just
think that Eclipse has one broken feature. That's bad and at the very least user
should be told what to do in (not that unusual I think) situation.

The ext connection method is still required since there are other connection 
tools than SSH (e.g. rsh). They are not used frequently but they are used. We 
already have a bug report or two about improving the error handling for ext.
